Federated Learning as a Network Effects Game

Shengyuan Hu Carnegie Mellon University, {shengyua, shuranzh, smithv, zstevenwu}@cmu.edu Dung Daniel Ngo University of Minnesota, {ngo00054}@umn.edu Shuran Zheng Carnegie Mellon University, {shengyua, shuranzh, smithv, zstevenwu}@cmu.edu Virginia Smith Carnegie Mellon University, {shengyua, shuranzh, smithv, zstevenwu}@cmu.edu Zhiwei Steven Wu Carnegie Mellon University, {shengyua, shuranzh, smithv, zstevenwu}@cmu.edu
Abstract

Federated Learning (FL) aims to foster collaboration among a population of clients to improve the accuracy of machine learning without directly sharing local data. Although there has been rich literature on designing federated learning algorithms, most prior works implicitly assume that all clients are willing to participate in a FL scheme. In practice, clients may not benefit from joining in FL, especially in light of potential costs related to issues such as privacy and computation. In this work, we study the clients’ incentives in federated learning to help the service provider design better solutions and ensure clients make better decisions. We are the first to model clients’ behaviors in FL as a network effects game, where each client’s benefit depends on other clients who also join the network. Using this setup we analyze the dynamics of clients’ participation and characterize the equilibrium, where no client has incentives to alter their decision. Specifically, we show that dynamics in the population naturally converge to equilibrium without needing explicit interventions. Finally, we provide a cost-efficient payment scheme that incentivizes clients to reach a desired equilibrium when the initial network is empty.

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) is a distributed learning paradigm that enables a network of clients (e.g., mobile devices, hospitals) to jointly learn a model without sharing their private local data McMahan et al. (2017); Kairouz et al. (2021). In real-world applications, the performance of the model on a particular client may not be improved through federation due to heterogeneity in the data generated by federated networks (Li et al., 2021). Moreover, even if a particular client has improved model utility on their local data by joining FL training, they may suffer from costs induced by joining the federated network. For example, the communication or latency in FL may affect the quality of clients’ user experience and the clients may suffer some privacy costs for sharing sensitive information. Understanding client incentives in FL is crucial for the service provider to design better solutions and for each client to make better decisions.

There is growing literature on incentive mechanisms in federated learning. Most of these works aim to study how to combine the data from all the clients to achieve a low error rate and ensure fairness for participating clients. However, these works are often based on a common assumption that all clients are willing participants who will join the federated network in order to achieve different learning goals (e.g., minimize the sample complexity (Blum et al., 2021), learn coalition structures (Donahue and Kleinberg, 2021c), etc.) In practice, rational clients can decide to either opt-in or opt-out of federated training based on their utility gain and cost as the network grows over time. The formal study of such a dynamic has not been captured in prior works studying incentives in federated learning.

Understanding how incentives change in response to varying client participation is essential for the successful development of incentive mechanisms in federated learning. In this work, we propose to model the clients’ behaviors in FL through the lens of network effects games (Katz and Shapiro, 1985; Shapiro and Varian, 2008). A network effects game models the benefit of each individual after aligning their behavior with the behaviors of other people in a coalition. This participation game closely relates to the client’s behavior in FL where joining the federated training improves the utility compared to only training a model on local data. Traditionally, network effects games have not been looked at in the context of FL or more broadly, data sharing. Existing work in FL typically models client participation as a one-time game where the clients arrive and make decisions once before leaving. We instead focus on modeling the dynamic of client participation in a setting where (1) each client incurs a cost while joining the network, and (2) each client is willing to join the network if and only if their utility gain outweighs the cost. The goal of our network effects analysis is to find an equilibrium where no client has an incentive to alter their decision.

Based on such a formulation, we consider two settings: (1) a simple and stylized mean estimation problem (Section 4) and (2) a general setting that requires an oracle reporting the true utility of being in a coalition to all clients (Section 5). For each setting, we fully characterize the dynamics of the client participation game under the network effects model. A key feature of FL is that clients’ utility of joining depends on the number of participants/data points. Since different clients may have different utilities and costs, it may be easier to gradually incentivize participation over time. For example, we may first target the clients who have lower costs and are more willing to join, and their participation will increase other participants’ willingness to join, and so on. Based on this characterization, we design a cost-effective payment scheme that gradually targets a subset of clients over time to reach a desirable equilibrium in Section 6. We summarize our contributions below:

  • •

    We propose to model the clients’ behaviors in a dynamic federated learning setting as a network effects game, in which clients’ utilities depend on the number of participants. We want to find the self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium in FL, when the outcome of the clients’ best-response strategy matches the shared expectation.

  • •

    We characterize all self-fulfilling expectation equilibria of the federated network effects game in a mean estimation problem and when there exists an oracle broadcasting the true utility of joining the coalition to all clients.

  • •

    We show that as clients continually best respond to public information, their dynamics naturally converge to an equilibrium where no clients have incentives to alter their decision.

  • •

    Finally, we provide a cost-efficient payment scheme that incentivizes clients to reach a desired equilibrium. Our result shows that for the dynamic to converge to a higher point, the server only needs to give payment until the coalition has reached a tipping point.

2 Related work

Incentives in federated learning.

Prior works that study incentive mechanisms in the context of federated learning typically aim to encourage clients to join in training in a one-time setting. Here we list the most relevant works, and defer readers to (Tu et al., 2022) for a more comprehensive discussion of work in the area. Works on collaborative learning such as Blum et al. (2017); Haghtalab et al. (2022) describe the approach of handling heterogeneous data to learn a common concept by iteratively gathering more data. For the application of federated learning, Donahue and Kleinberg (2021c, a, b) analyzes the coalition structure for federated mean estimation and linear regression problems using hedonic game theory, and Cho et al. (2022) proposes a new FL objective that aims at increasing the number of incentivized clients. Our method differs from the above works in that apart from utility gain, our work considers the cost of joining the federated network as a factor that can dynamically affect client behavior.

More related are the works of Blum et al. (2021), which analyzes a framework for incentive-aware data sharing in FL under the notion of envy, and Karimireddy et al. (2022), which introduces an accuracy-based algorithm to maximize the amount of data contributed by each client to learn their local mean parameter. While these two works share some similarities with ours in that they encode some form of joining cost, our method focuses on studying the dynamics of the population and analyzing the equilibrium when clients best respond to public information.

Finally, we note that the use of financial incentives as a means of motivating clients has been a topic of extensive research. Various economic approaches have been proposed to monetarily incentivize participation, e.g., via auctions/reversed auctions (Kim, 2020; Thi Le et al., 2021), contract theory approaches Saputra et al. (2020), public good approaches Tang and Wong (2021). Our work adds a new perspective to this area by studying how participation changes over time and considering payments only at tipping points of the dynamic.

Network effects.

Our work draws inspiration from literature on network effects games (e.g., Katz and Shapiro, 1985; Shapiro and Varian, 2008; Easley and Kleinberg, 2010), where the utility of a client using a service depends on the number of other clients participating in the same service. This effect is often positive, as clients gain more utility from others joining the network. In our model, we consider accuracy improvement from having more data in a coalition as a natural incentive mechanism: As clients join the FL process, they expect to obtain a more accurate estimator from the combined data of all clients in the coalition. To the best of our knowledge, we are the first to model network effects in FL in this manner, and our work is the first to study the behavior of rational clients in FL under the network effects model. In formulating and analyzing this dynamic perspective on client incentives, we hope that our work can lead to future study and development of FL incentive mechanisms that more closely mirror practical FL applications.

3 Problem Formulation and Preliminaries

In this section, we first introduce the setup of our federated learning problem. We then characterize the incentive and utility gain for each client from joining the federated learning process and their interaction with the server. Finally, we propose a general framework of federated learning as a dynamic network effects game.

3.1 Learning Problem Formulation

We consider a federated learning setup where there are M𝑀M clients in the population who want to solve a common learning problem. For each client i∈[M]𝑖delimited-[]𝑀i\in[M], we assume that they want to minimize their loss function given by fi​(𝐰)=𝔼ξ∼𝒟i​[ℓ​(𝐰,ξ)]subscript𝑓𝑖𝐰subscript𝔼similar-to𝜉subscript𝒟𝑖delimited-[]ℓ𝐰𝜉f_{i}(\mathbf{w})=\mathbb{E}_{\xi\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}}[\ell(\mathbf{w},\xi)], where 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} is the target data distribution of client i𝑖i, and ℓ​(𝐰,ξ)ℓ𝐰𝜉\ell(\mathbf{w},\xi) is the loss function for a model 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} for data sample ξ𝜉\xi. There are two possibilities: all clients share a target distribution 𝒟i=𝒟subscript𝒟𝑖𝒟\mathcal{D}_{i}=\mathcal{D}, e.g., global mean estimation, and when clients have different target distribution 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}, e.g., personalized local mean estimation. In practice, each client only has access to its local training dataset with nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} data point sampled i.i.d from data distribution 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}.

Client Incentive and Utility Gain.

The goal of each client i𝑖i is to find a model 𝐰i∗subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑖\mathbf{w}^{*}_{i} that minimize its true loss function, i.e., 𝐰i∗≔arg⁡min𝐰⁡fi​(𝐰)≔subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑖subscript𝐰subscript𝑓𝑖𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*}_{i}\coloneqq\arg\min_{\mathbf{w}}f_{i}(\mathbf{w}). We assume that each client will perform local training on their own dataset to obtain a local model 𝐰^isubscript^𝐰𝑖\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{i}. Since the local dataset has a small size, the local model 𝐰^isubscript^𝐰𝑖\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{i} might not generalize well to the target distribution 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}. Hence, a client would consider participating in the federated learning process if the federated model gives a better generalization performance compared to its local model. We define the expected utility gain of joining a coalition S𝑆S for a client i𝑖i as the difference between the true loss using the local model 𝐰^isubscript^𝐰𝑖\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{i} and the federated model 𝐰Ssubscript𝐰𝑆\mathbf{w}_{S} on the target distribution 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}:

Ui=𝔼𝒟i​[fi​(𝐰S)−fi​(𝐰i^)]subscript𝑈𝑖subscript𝔼subscript𝒟𝑖delimited-[]subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐰𝑆subscript𝑓𝑖^subscript𝐰𝑖U_{i}=\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{D}_{i}}[f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{S})-f_{i}(\hat{\mathbf{w}_{i}})]

Bayesian priors.

We assume each client i𝑖i has a Bayesian belief about a model’s true loss as a function of the number of samples used in the model. That is, given the local sample size and the coalition size, each client i𝑖i can infer the losses fi​(𝐰^i)subscript𝑓𝑖subscript^𝐰𝑖f_{i}(\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{i}) and fi​(𝐰S)subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐰𝑆f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{S}). Hence, given the shared expectation K𝐾K, the clients have some belief about their expected utility gain for joining the coalition. When the clients’ belief exactly matches the actual utility gain of joining, this belief is equivalent to the clients observing the true utility from an oracle.

Personal cost.

If a client i𝑖i in the population decides to join the coalition, they will incur some fixed cost ci>0subscript𝑐𝑖0c_{i}>0. This cost cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i} contains the enrollment and communication cost of joining the coalition. The cost may also represent the privacy loss for the client i𝑖i from revealing information about their local data to the server. For example, a server can charge each participating hospital a fixed fee for using the shared model. At each time step, each hospital needs to communicate with the server to update its knowledge base and decide to either opt-in or opt-out. Finally, due to the sensitive nature of medical data and how each individual model is trained, the hospitals will also incur some privacy loss for sharing their model with the server.

Interaction between clients and server.

Given a coalition S𝑆S, a client has to decide whether to join the coalition or use only their local data. We assume that if the utility gain from joining the coalition is less than the personal costs for a client i∈[M]𝑖delimited-[]𝑀i\in[M], then client i𝑖i would not join the coalition. That is, given a coalition S𝑆S and a client i∈[M]𝑖delimited-[]𝑀i\in[M] with cost cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i} where Ui≥cisubscript𝑈𝑖subscript𝑐𝑖U_{i}\geq c_{i}, then client i𝑖i would opt in the federated learning process. Otherwise, if the utility gain is less than that of the personal cost cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i}, then client i𝑖i would opt out of the federated learning process.

3.2 FL as Dynamic Network Effects Game

We model the dynamic of the population in federated learning as a network effects game. Whenever all clients in the population share an expectation that K𝐾K samples are in the coalition, each client i∈[M]𝑖delimited-[]𝑀i\in[M] can calculate their expected utility gain as a function of K𝐾K, i.e., Ui=Ui​(K)subscript𝑈𝑖subscript𝑈𝑖𝐾U_{i}=U_{i}(K) and compare it to their cost cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i}. After a coalition is formed, all clients in the population can observe the actual number of samples h​(K)ℎ𝐾h(K) in the coalition and update their shared expectations for the next time step. Formally, we describe the participation decision of the clients at each time step in Algorithm 1. We define the realization mapping between the shared expectation K𝐾K and the actual outcome in the coalition as h:ℤ+→ℤ+:ℎ→superscriptℤsuperscriptℤh:\mathbb{Z}^{+}\rightarrow\mathbb{Z}^{+}, i.e., if the shared expectation is K𝐾K, then the actual outcome in the coalition is h​(K)ℎ𝐾h(K).

As a result, clients can compute their utility gain according to the new expectation and decide to either stay/join the coalition or leave. For example, if there are more samples in the coalition than expected, i.e., h​(K)≥Kℎ𝐾𝐾h(K)\geq K then the utility gain from joining increases. As a result, some new clients now have positive expected utility gains and are willing to join the coalition. On the other hand, if there are fewer samples in the coalition than expected, the expected utility gain would decrease. Some clients who were previously in the coalition would leave as their utility gain is lower than their cost, while other clients have no incentives to join. We aim to study the dynamic of the population and characterize a suitable equilibrium under these behaviors.

If the clients’ shared expectation is perfect, we can define an equilibrium notion. If all clients form a shared expectation that there are K𝐾K samples in the coalition, and if each of them decides to either join or leave the coalition based on this expectation, then the actual number of samples in the coalition is K𝐾K. We call this a self-fulfilling expectation for the number of samples K𝐾K:

Definition 1 (Self-Fulfilling Expectation Equilibrium).

Consider a population where all clients share an expectation that there are K𝐾K samples in the coalition. If the actual number of samples in the coalition is h​(K)=Kℎ𝐾𝐾h(K)=K, then K𝐾K is called a self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium.

By its definition, if we know function h​(K)ℎ𝐾h(K), we can find the self-fulfilling equilibria by locating the integral crossing points of h​(K)ℎ𝐾h(K) and the identity function f​(K)=K𝑓𝐾𝐾f(K)=K. But the question is: do they always cross at integer points? We show by the following theorem that whenever we have h​(K)≥Kℎ𝐾𝐾h(K)\geq K, we are guaranteed to find an integral equilibrium h​(K∗)=K∗ℎsuperscript𝐾superscript𝐾h(K^{*})=K^{*} to the right of K𝐾K.

As we will show in our analysis, we can identify self-fulfilling expectation equilibria in the dynamic as long as the realization mapping h​(⋅)ℎ⋅h(\cdot) is monotonically non-decreasing for some stylized learning problems.

Theorem 2 (Existence of Self-Fulfilling Expectation Equilibrium).

In FL under the dynamic network effects game model, if the realization mapping h(.)h(.) is monotonically non-decreasing, for any positive K𝐾K with h​(K)≥Kℎ𝐾𝐾h(K)\geq K, we can find a self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium h​(K∗)=K∗ℎsuperscript𝐾superscript𝐾h(K^{*})=K^{*} to the right of K𝐾K, i.e., K∗≥Ksuperscript𝐾𝐾K^{*}\geq K. For any point in between K′∈(K,K∗)superscript𝐾′𝐾superscript𝐾K^{\prime}\in(K,K^{*}), we have h​(K′)>K′ℎsuperscript𝐾′superscript𝐾′h(K^{\prime})>K^{\prime}.

Characterizing self-fulfilling expectation equilibria is crucial to the server and policymakers who wish to understand and influence where the dynamic converges. In Section 4 and 5, we show that Theorem 2 is true for two stylized settings of mean estimation and utility oracle. In Section 6, we show that the server use properties of the equilibria to guarantee that the final coalition reaches the maximum size equilibrium by paying a subset of clients.

Stable equilibrium.

When the population is at equilibrium, it could still be susceptible to small perturbations when a client decides to join or leave the coalition. Consider an extreme instance where the highest cost of joining for a client is the same as the utility gain at every value K𝐾K, i.e. ∀K∈[M]:cK=UK:for-all𝐾delimited-[]𝑀subscript𝑐𝐾subscript𝑈𝐾\forall K\in[M]:c_{K}=U_{K}. Then, by definition, every value K𝐾K is a self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium. Hence, at each value K∈[M−1]𝐾delimited-[]𝑀1K\in[M-1], new clients still have incentives to join the coalition as their cost of joining is exactly the same as the utility gain. In this instance, subject to small perturbation, the dynamic will converge to either 00, where no client is in the coalition, or M𝑀M, where every client is in the coalition. These equilibrium values where no client has incentives to join or leave are called stable equilibrium. Formally, we define stable equilibrium as:

Definition 3 (Stable Equilibrium (Jackson and Yariv, 2007)).

An equilibrium K∗superscript𝐾K^{*} is stable if there exists ϵ′>0superscriptitalic-ϵ′0\epsilon^{\prime}>0 such that h​(K∗−ϵ)>K∗−ϵℎsuperscript𝐾italic-ϵsuperscript𝐾italic-ϵh(K^{*}-\epsilon)>K^{*}-\epsilon and h​(K∗+ϵ)<K∗+ϵℎsuperscript𝐾italic-ϵsuperscript𝐾italic-ϵh(K^{*}+\epsilon)<K^{*}+\epsilon for all ϵ′>ϵ>0superscriptitalic-ϵ′italic-ϵ0\epsilon^{\prime}>\epsilon>0. An equilibrium K𝐾K is unstable (tipping point) if there exists ϵ′>0superscriptitalic-ϵ′0\epsilon^{\prime}>0 such that h​(K−ϵ)<K−ϵℎ𝐾italic-ϵ𝐾italic-ϵh(K-\epsilon)<K-\epsilon and h​(K+ϵ)>K+ϵℎ𝐾italic-ϵ𝐾italic-ϵh(K+\epsilon)>K+\epsilon for all ϵ′>ϵ>0superscriptitalic-ϵ′italic-ϵ0\epsilon^{\prime}>\epsilon>0.

In the example above, all values K∈[1,K−1]𝐾1𝐾1K\in[1,K-1] are the tipping points. With this definition, we can analyze the dynamics of the population. Informally, if the initial expectation is not a stable equilibrium, then the clients can continually update their shared expectations and decide to either join or leave the coalition. This decision-making process ends when the shared expectation is at a stable equilibrium, where with a small perturbation to the coalition, there is no incentive for any client to change their decision.

Theorem 4 (Convergence to stable equilibrium).

In FL under the dynamic network effects game model, if clients share an expectation K𝐾K with h​(K)>Kℎ𝐾𝐾h(K)>K then the coalition size will grow in the next time step. Otherwise, if h​(K)<Kℎ𝐾𝐾h(K)<K, then the coalition size will shrink in the next time step. If the shared expectation is between a tipping point K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime} and a stable equilibrium K∗superscript𝐾K^{*}, then the dynamic will converge to the stable equilibrium K∗superscript𝐾K^{*}.

In our analysis, we assume that there always exists one trivial self-fulfilling expectation at 00, i.e., if all clients expect that no one would join then there are no samples in the coalition and Ui​(0)=0subscript𝑈𝑖00U_{i}(0)=0. Since the cost of joining for a client i𝑖i is ci>0subscript𝑐𝑖0c_{i}>0, no client would join the coalition. In our analysis, we always assume the initial expectation is positive unless specified otherwise. We write equilibrium as shorthand for self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium.

Remark 5 (Stable equilibrium is a Nash equilibrium).

First, we observe that not every self-fulfilling equilibrium is a Nash equilibrium. Consider the example where the cost of joining is equal to the utility gain at every value of K𝐾K. Then at some tipping point K𝐾K, given the decision of every other client, a client K+1𝐾1K+1 who is not in the coalition can potentially join and increase their utility. Hence, the tipping point K𝐾K is not a Nash equilibrium.

On the other hand, a stable equilibrium K∗superscript𝐾K^{*} is a Nash equilibrium. By definition, when the shared expectation is K∗superscript𝐾K^{*}, no client in the population has incentives to change their decision. Hence, the set of stable equilibrium is an intersection of Nash equilibria and self-fulfilling equilibria.

4 Network Effects game in a Mean Estimation Problem

In this section, we investigate how the dynamic behaves in a stylized global mean estimation problem. First, we formally describe the setup when there all clients in the population have the same number of local samples. Then, we show that Theorem 2 is true in this setting with some simple cost functions. Finally, we show that the dynamic naturally converges to a stable equilibrium where no clients have further incentive to change their decisions.

Mean Estimation Problem Setup.

There are M𝑀M clients in the population who want to solve a common mean estimation problem. Each client i𝑖i has a fixed number of samples nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} and a cost cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i}. First, each client i𝑖i draws their mean parameter μisubscript𝜇𝑖\mu_{i} i.i.d from a common prior with mean θ𝜃\theta: μi∼𝒩​(θ,σθ2)similar-tosubscript𝜇𝑖𝒩𝜃superscriptsubscript𝜎𝜃2\mu_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(\theta,\sigma_{\theta}^{2}). W.L.O.G, we assume that client i𝑖i draws their samples i.i.d from a unit variant Gaussian with local mean μisubscript𝜇𝑖\mu_{i}: Xi∼𝒩​(μi,1)similar-tosubscript𝑋𝑖𝒩subscript𝜇𝑖1X_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(\mu_{i},1). Formally, the clients want to find an estimator w𝑤w such that the mean squared error (MSE) 𝔼​[(θ−w)2]𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝜃𝑤2\mathbb{E}[(\theta-w)^{2}] is minimized. We first focus our analysis on the case where all clients in the population have the same number of local data to highlight the dynamic behavior. We defer the discussion of the general case where clients have different numbers of local samples to the appendix.

For a client i𝑖i, if they do not join the coalition, their estimator is simply the empirical average over their local data samples 𝐰i=1/ni​∑j=1nixi,jsubscript𝐰𝑖1subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗\mathbf{w}_{i}=\nicefrac{{1}}{{n_{i}}}\sum_{j=1}^{n_{i}}x_{i,j}. Otherwise, if the client decides to join a coalition S𝑆S, we assume they will send their local estimator wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i} to the server for aggregation. The server then computes a coalition estimator, which we assume is a weighted average over the local estimators of participating clients in S𝑆S: 𝐰S=1/NS​∑j∈Swj⋅njsubscript𝐰𝑆1subscript𝑁𝑆subscript𝑗𝑆⋅subscript𝑤𝑗subscript𝑛𝑗\mathbf{w}_{S}=\nicefrac{{1}}{{N_{S}}}\sum_{j\in S}w_{j}\cdot n_{j} where NSsubscript𝑁𝑆N_{S} is the total number of samples in the coalition.

Since all clients have the same number of local samples ni=nsubscript𝑛𝑖𝑛n_{i}=n and the expected number of clients in the coalition is K𝐾K, the utility gain function for a client i𝑖i is:

Ui=U​(K,n)=K−1K​n+3​K2−5​K+2K2​σθ2subscript𝑈𝑖𝑈𝐾𝑛𝐾1𝐾𝑛3superscript𝐾25𝐾2superscript𝐾2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝜃U_{i}=U(K,n)=\frac{K-1}{Kn}+\frac{3K^{2}-5K+2}{K^{2}}\sigma^{2}_{\theta} (1)

When all clients have the same number of local samples, we slightly abuse the notation and write K𝐾K as the expected number of clients in the coalition instead of the expected number of samples. Similarly, h​(K)ℎ𝐾h(K) represents the actual number of clients in the coalition in this setting.

Since all clients have the same number of local samples, the equilibrium only needs to consider the number of clients in the coalition. Our first result here is a sufficient condition for such an equilibrium to exist. Next, we explore some desirable properties of self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium, i.e., characterizing a subset of equilibrium that is stable where no clients in the population have incentives to change their decision. We formally show that under the network effect model, all dynamics will converge to a stable self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium. Finally, we provide sufficient conditions for such a stable equilibrium to exist.

4.1 Existence of a Self-fulfilling Expectation Equilibrium

Realization mapping h​(⋅)ℎ⋅h(\cdot).

Since all clients have the same number of local samples, W.L.O.G, we can order them according to their personal cost in ascending order. Moreover, we assume that the cost of joining for a client i𝑖i is a continuous positive monotonically non-decreasing function of their index i𝑖i, i.e., ci=c​(i)subscript𝑐𝑖𝑐𝑖c_{i}=c(i). In our analysis, we only look at the cost function for integer value i𝑖i. If all clients share a common belief that K𝐾K clients will join the coalition, then client i𝑖i would join only if U​(K,n)≥c​(i)𝑈𝐾𝑛𝑐𝑖U(K,n)\geq c(i). Hence, if any client would join at all, then the set of clients joining would be between 111 and K^^𝐾\hat{K}, where

h​(K)=inf{x∈ℝ:U​(K,n)≥c​(i)}ℎ𝐾infimumconditional-set𝑥ℝ𝑈𝐾𝑛𝑐𝑖h(K)=\inf\{x\in\mathbb{R}:U(K,n)\geq c(i)\}

Hence, we can find the equilibrium by solving U​(K,n)=c​(h​(K))𝑈𝐾𝑛𝑐ℎ𝐾U(K,n)=c(h(K)). Fixing the number of local samples n𝑛n, this equation is equivalent to solving

h​(K)=c−1​(U​(K,n))ℎ𝐾superscript𝑐1𝑈𝐾𝑛h(K)=c^{-1}(U(K,n))

Formally, we define the mapping between the expectation K𝐾K and the actual number of clients in the coalition K^^𝐾\hat{K} as h:[M]→[M]:ℎ→delimited-[]𝑀delimited-[]𝑀h:[M]\rightarrow[M], where

h​(x)=c−1​(U​(x))ℎ𝑥superscript𝑐1𝑈𝑥h(x)=c^{-1}(U(x))

Hence, if we exactly know the cost function c​(⋅)𝑐⋅c(\cdot) and the expected utility gain U​(K,n)𝑈𝐾𝑛U(K,n), we can find an equilibrium in the population. Since c​(i)𝑐𝑖c(i) is monotone non-decreasing, its inverse function h​(⋅)ℎ⋅h(\cdot) is also monotone non-decreasing.

Moreover, we prove that there always exists an equilibrium under some mild assumption on shared expectation K𝐾K and the actual number of clients in the coalition h​(K)ℎ𝐾h(K). Informally, if the shared expectation K𝐾K is pessimistic compared to the actual outcome h​(K)ℎ𝐾h(K), then we can always find an equilibrium. The clients would update their expectations and join the coalition due to a new higher utility gain. However, as the h​(⋅)ℎ⋅h(\cdot) function is non-decreasing, there exist some clients whose utility gain is less than the cost of joining and they do not have incentives to join the coalition.

Corollary 6.

In the mean estimation problem where all clients have the same number of local samples, for any positive K>0𝐾0K>0 with h​(K)≥Kℎ𝐾𝐾h(K)\geq K, we can find a self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium h​(K∗)=K∗ℎsuperscript𝐾superscript𝐾h(K^{*})=K^{*} to the right of K𝐾K with K∗≥Ksuperscript𝐾𝐾K^{*}\geq K; and for any point in between K′∈(K,K∗)superscript𝐾′𝐾superscript𝐾K^{\prime}\in(K,K^{*}), we have h​(K′)>K′ℎsuperscript𝐾′superscript𝐾′h(K^{\prime})>K^{\prime}.

This result can also be interpreted as every time the actual number of clients in the coalition K^^𝐾\hat{K} equals or exceeds the expectation K𝐾K, we must have an equilibrium. Under this assumption, we can derive a sufficient condition on the cost function c​(⋅)𝑐⋅c(\cdot) so there exists an equilibrium. Note that h​(K)ℎ𝐾h(K) is a composition of the cost function c​(i)𝑐𝑖c(i) and the utility function U​(K,n)𝑈𝐾𝑛U(K,n). Since the cost function c​(⋅)𝑐⋅c(\cdot) is monotonically non-decreasing, we can apply c​(⋅)𝑐⋅c(\cdot) to both sides of the sufficient condition in Corollary 6 and obtain an equivalent condition: an equilibrium exists as long as there exists an expectation K𝐾K such that U​(K,n)≥c​(K)𝑈𝐾𝑛𝑐𝐾U(K,n)\geq c(K).

4.2 Convergence to Stable Equilibrium

We derive a sufficient condition for a population to have a stable equilibrium. Informally, a stable equilibrium exists when all clients are in the coalition or if the cost of joining for client K∗+1superscript𝐾1K^{*}+1 is larger than the utility gain from joining.

Corollary 7.

In the mean estimation problem when all clients have the same number of local samples, a stable equilibrium h​(K∗)=K∗ℎsuperscript𝐾superscript𝐾h(K^{*})=K^{*} exists as long as there exists an equilibrium K∗superscript𝐾K^{*} with h​(K∗+1)<K∗+1ℎsuperscript𝐾1superscript𝐾1h(K^{*}+1)<K^{*}+1 or K∗=Msuperscript𝐾𝑀K^{*}=M.

Finally, we show that Theorem 4 applies and the dynamic would naturally converge to the stable equilibrium.

Corollary 8 (Convergence to stable equilibrium in mean estimation setting).

In the mean estimation problem when all clients have the same number of local samples, if an expectation K𝐾K is between a tipping point K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime} and a stable equilibrium K∗superscript𝐾K^{*}, then the dynamic will converge to K∗superscript𝐾K^{*}.

4.3 Extension: when clients have different numbers of local samples

In the previous analysis, we studied a stylized setting where all clients have the same number of local samples. When clients have a different number of samples, this analysis does not easily generalize since we cannot directly infer the utility gain from the expected number of samples K𝐾K. Notably, in Equation 38, the cross term ∑i≠jj∈Snj2superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑗𝑗𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑗2\sum_{i\neq j}^{j\in S}n_{j}^{2} requires the clients to have knowledge of the coalition composition to calculate the expected utility gain. Hence, we need an additional step where the clients form a shared expectation of the utility gain before making their decision. Our first result here is a sufficient condition for an equilibrium to exist. Then, we proceed to show that the dynamic would converge to a stable equilibrium.

Inferring Coalition from Shared Expectation

First, we investigate how the clients infer the coalition composition based on the expected number of samples K𝐾K in the coalition. Assuming that the number of local samples nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} and the personal cost cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i} for each client i∈[M]𝑖delimited-[]𝑀i\in[M] are public information, the server can separate the utility gain function into two parts: a fixed gain using data from other clients in the coalition and the additional gain by having their personal data in the coalition. That is, for a client i𝑖i with nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} local samples, the utility gain for joining the coalition is

Ui​({nj}j∈S)=1−NS−(∑j∈Snj2NS2−3)​σθ2⏟fixed gain+1ni+(2​ni2NS2−4​niNS)​σθ2⏟additional gainsubscript𝑈𝑖subscriptsubscript𝑛𝑗𝑗𝑆subscript⏟1subscript𝑁𝑆subscript𝑗𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝑛2𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑁2𝑆3subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝜃fixed gainsubscript⏟1subscript𝑛𝑖2subscriptsuperscript𝑛2𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑁2𝑆4subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑁𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝜃additional gain\displaystyle U_{i}(\{n_{j}\}_{j\in S})=\underbrace{\frac{1}{-N_{S}}-\left(\frac{\sum_{j\in S}n^{2}_{j}}{N^{2}_{S}}-3\right)\sigma^{2}_{\theta}}_{\text{fixed gain}}+\underbrace{\frac{1}{n_{i}}+\left(\frac{2n^{2}_{i}}{N^{2}_{S}}-\frac{4n_{i}}{N_{S}}\right)\sigma^{2}_{\theta}}_{\text{additional gain}} (2)

These clients can compute their utility Ui​(K)=Ui​({nj}j∈SI​(K))subscript𝑈𝑖𝐾subscript𝑈𝑖subscriptsubscript𝑛𝑗𝑗subscript𝑆𝐼𝐾U_{i}(K)=U_{i}(\{n_{j}\}_{j\in S_{I}(K)}) and decide to join or not by comparing it with their cost cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i}. With this inferred coalition, we can analyze the self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium in this setting. The rest of the analysis in this section follows the same proof technique as the previous setting where all clients have the same number of local samples. The first result here is that we can prove Theorem 2 in the mean estimation problem when clients have different numbers of local samples:

Corollary 9.

In the mean estimation problem where clients have different numbers of local samples, the realization mapping is h​(K)=∑j=1tnj⋅𝟏​{Uj≥cj}ℎ𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑡⋅subscript𝑛𝑗1subscript𝑈𝑗subscript𝑐𝑗h(K)=\sum_{j=1}^{t}n_{j}\cdot\mathbf{1}\{U_{j}\geq c_{j}\} where Uj​(K)subscript𝑈𝑗𝐾U_{j}(K) is defined in Equation 3. Finally, we also show that Theorem 4 also apply to this setting and the dynamic will converge to a stable equilibrium:

Corollary 10 (Convergence to stable equilibrium).

In the mean estimation problem where clients have different numbers of local samples, if an expectation K𝐾K is initialized between a tipping point K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime} and a stable equilibrium K∗superscript𝐾K^{*}, then the dynamic will converge to K∗superscript𝐾K^{*}.

5 Network Effects in FL with Utility Oracle

In the previous analysis, we rely on the assumption that all clients are trying to solve a common global mean estimation problem to derive the exact utility gain function. The clients then make their opt-in/opt-out decisions based on this expected utility gain value. How would the clients’ behavior change if the server and the clients do not know how to calculate the utility gain, but instead observe it from some oracle for some general learning problem? In this section, we will study this question assuming the underlying utility gain function is monotonically non-decreasing with regard to the total number of samples in the coalition. Since the utility gain function Equation 1 in the homogeneous setting satisfies our monotonicity assumption and we are considering a more general learning problem, the utility oracle setting is strictly more general than the mean estimation setting. First, we formalize our definition of self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium with utility oracle. Then, we show that the dynamic will always converge to a self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium with proof by induction.

5.1 Client/Server Interaction with a Utility Oracle

Consider a population of M𝑀M clients who want to solve a common learning problem over a time horizon T>0𝑇0T>0. At t=0𝑡0t=0, there exists a non-empty arbitrary coalition S(0)superscript𝑆0S^{(0)} consisting of some clients in the population. Suppose at each time step t𝑡t, there is an oracle that broadcast a message to all the clients about the true utility of joining the coalition based on the previous time step t−1𝑡1t-1 regardless of their current participation status. That is, given the coalition S(t)superscript𝑆𝑡S^{(t)} on time step t𝑡t, a client i∈[M]𝑖delimited-[]𝑀i\in[M] knows Ui(t)=u​({nj}j∈S(t),i)superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑡𝑢subscriptsubscript𝑛𝑗𝑗superscript𝑆𝑡𝑖U_{i}^{(t)}=u(\{n_{j}\}_{j\in S^{(t)}},i) if client i𝑖i is currently in the coalition. Otherwise, if i𝑖i is not in the coalition, then client i𝑖i can know Ui(t)=u​({nj}j∈S(t)∪{i},i)superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑡𝑢subscriptsubscript𝑛𝑗𝑗superscript𝑆𝑡𝑖𝑖U_{i}^{(t)}=u(\{n_{j}\}_{j\in S^{(t)}\cup\{i\}},i). With this observed utility, at the next time step t+1𝑡1t+1, clients i∈[M]𝑖delimited-[]𝑀i\in[M] would opt-in the coalition if Ui(t)≥cisuperscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑡subscript𝑐𝑖U_{i}^{(t)}\geq c_{i} and leave the coalition otherwise.

In our analysis, we assume that this observed oracle utility only depends on the size of the coalition and the opt-in/opt-out decisions of other clients in the coalition. This assumption aligns with how the utility gain function was defined for the homogeneous setting in Equation 1. With this interaction protocol, we note that there is no longer a need for the population to form an expectation over the size of the coalition at each time step. Instead, clients i∈[M]𝑖delimited-[]𝑀i\in[M] would use the oracle utility of the previous time step t−1𝑡1t-1 as the expected utility for time step t𝑡t, i.e., 𝔼​[Ui(t)]=Ui(t−1)𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑡1\mathbb{E}[U_{i}^{(t)}]=U_{i}^{(t-1)}. We rewrite the definition of self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium for the oracle utility setting as:

Definition 11 (Self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium with oracle utility).

Consider a population in which all clients observe oracle utility at time step t𝑡t with K𝐾K samples in the coalition. If the actual number of samples in the coalition at time step t+1𝑡1t+1 is also K𝐾K, then K𝐾K is called a self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium.

That is, at every time step, the clients can best respond to the observed oracle utility and change their participation status. Since clients are behaving in a myopic way with limited information, if the coalition stays the same in two consecutive time steps, then it would also stay the same for the rest of the time horizon. With our assumption that the utility gain only depends on the number of samples in the coalition, this condition is equivalent to the coalition having the same size in two consecutive time steps.

5.2 Existence of Self-fulfilling Expectation Equilibrium

We prove that there always exists an equilibrium if the observed utility gain for all clients in the population satisfies the monotonicity assumption. Informally, if the coalition grows in size in the first few time steps, all clients in the population would observe an increased utility gain from participating in the federated learning process. Hence, new clients j∉S𝑗𝑆j\notin S with Ui(t)≥cisuperscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑡subscript𝑐𝑖U_{i}^{(t)}\geq c_{i} would join the coalition while opted-in clients i∈S𝑖𝑆i\in S do not have the incentive to leave. Since the size of the coalition does not decrease at each time step, this effect would cascade until the coalition has reached an equilibrium, where the extra utility from having more clients is not sufficient for new clients to join the coalition. On the other hand, if the initial coalition contains some clients with very high costs who would leave in the first few time steps, then all clients would observe a decreased utility gain in future time steps. Hence, clients who have not already joined the coalition would no longer want to participate in the federated learning process. Moreover, clients who joined in previous time steps might leave once their decreased utility from a smaller coalition becomes lower than their personal cost. Therefore, the total number of samples in the coalition would shrink until we have reached a self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium.

Theorem 12.

Given a population where all clients observe the utility oracle regardless of their participation status, the dynamic will converge to a self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium. More specifically, there exists a time step t𝑡t, where S(t)superscript𝑆𝑡S^{(t)} is a self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium and S(t+1)=S(t)superscript𝑆𝑡1superscript𝑆𝑡S^{(t+1)}=S^{(t)} thereafter.

This result highlights the dynamic behavior of the population under the network effects model where clients are behaving in a myopic way with limited information. Under a mild assumption of monotonically increasing utility w.r.t the number of samples in the coalition and with any non-empty initial coalition, the dynamic always converges to a self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium. The monotonicity assumption is often justifiable—since all local samples are drawn i.i.d, having more samples in the coalition would intuitively produce a model with better accuracy in the mean estimation task. While the assumption of utility oracle is often not realistic, its inclusion removes the need for a closed-form expression for the utility gain function, which was previously needed in our analysis. As a result, our analysis here can also be applied to other learning problems that are not mean estimation as long as the utility gain for each client satisfies the monotonicity assumption.

6 Network Effects in FL with Payment

In the previous analysis, we implicitly assumed that the initial shared expectation and the initial coalition are non-empty. This assumption is made to prevent the dynamic from getting stuck at the trivial stable self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium of 00. Without any intervention from the server, no client would voluntarily join the coalition. In this section, we look at a possible solution to this problem as the server can start the dynamic from 00 by offering external incentives to a subset of clients. We begin with modeling a mechanism design problem where at every time step, the server wants to find the smallest payment that can kick start a dynamic convergence to the largest equilibrium. We then provide a characterization of the optimal payment mechanism for the server that relies on the number of tipping points and stable equilibria in the dynamic.

6.1 Payment Mechanism as an Optimization Problem

First, we consider the same setting where a population of clients wants to learn a common learning problem but the server can offer to subsidize the personal cost of some clients by waiving their enrollment fee for using the server’s aggregated model. Moreover, the server also provides extra payment to offset the privacy loss from sharing the client’s personal model trained on their own data samples. That is, a client i∈[M]𝑖delimited-[]𝑀i\in[M] with personal cost cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i} can have their entire cost subsidized by the server such that they can join the coalition for ’free’. We assume that at every time step, the server can broadcast a take-it-or-leave-it payment message to a subset of clients. For the server, if it pays K𝐾K clients to join the coalition, then the total amount of payment P𝑃P is the sum of the personal cost for these K𝐾K clients.

The mechanism design problem for the server can be seen as an optimization problem. Given the personal costs of all clients, we want to find the smallest payment such that the dynamic converges to the largest equilibrium. That is, for some small perturbation ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, all clients j𝑗j not in the coalition at the time horizon T𝑇T will not join the coalition even if there are ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon more samples in the coalition, and no clients in S𝑆S have incentives to leave. Formally, we have:

min⁡P𝑃\displaystyle\min P
s.t. {∀j∉S,Uj(T)​(NS+ϵ)<cj∀i∈S,Ui(T)​(NS)>cicasesformulae-sequencefor-all𝑗𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑗𝑇subscript𝑁𝑆italic-ϵsubscript𝑐𝑗otherwiseformulae-sequencefor-all𝑖𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑇subscript𝑁𝑆subscript𝑐𝑖otherwise\displaystyle\begin{cases}\forall j\notin S,U_{j}^{(T)}(N_{S}+\epsilon)<c_{j}\\ \forall i\in S,U_{i}^{(T)}(N_{S})>c_{i}\end{cases}

Alternatively, if the server has a payment budget B>0𝐵0B>0, then the optimization problem becomes finding the highest equilibrium point that the dynamic can possibly reach with a total payment of less than B𝐵B. Due to the stability property of some equilibria in the dynamic, the server would approach these two optimization problems with unlimited and limited budgets with the same strategy. In intuition, the optimal strategy involves paying a specific subset of clients at each time step to move the dynamic to a higher self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium. Since the number of paid clients is fixed at each time step, the server’s payment strategy is the same for both scenarios. From this point, we focus our analysis on the unlimited budget setting.

6.2 Payment in Mean Estimation Setting

First, we look at the mean estimation problem where all clients have the same number of local samples. If the initial shared expectation is 00, then we know that the expected utility of joining the coalition is also 00. Hence, no client would voluntarily join the coalition. From our analysis in Section 4, if the expectation is between a tipping point and a stable equilibrium then the dynamic would converge to the stable equilibrium. Hence, the server can minimize their total payment by first broadcasting a payment message to the first K0subscript𝐾0K_{0} clients with the lowest personal cost, where K0subscript𝐾0K_{0} is the smallest tipping point. If the initial coalition has fewer than K0subscript𝐾0K_{0} clients, then it would quickly collapse back to the trivial stable equilibrium of 00. Once the coalition has reached a tipping point, the server can help move the dynamic toward a higher tipping point simply by getting one new client to join. This new client would increase the expected utility gain of being in the coalition enough that other clients would also consider joining the coalition. This payment process would stop once the coalition has reached the highest equilibrium. We formalize the optimal payment strategy for the homogeneous setting as:

Theorem 13 (Incentive with payment in the mean estimation setting).

Consider a population in which all clients have the same number of local samples n𝑛n and a server that can repeatedly send payments to incentivize new clients at every round. The server would move the dynamic toward the highest equilibrium with the minimum total payment by sending a payment message to one new client with the smallest personal cost at every tipping point or to Khsubscript𝐾ℎK_{h} new clients at every stable equilibrium, where Khsubscript𝐾ℎK_{h} is the difference in the number of clients between the hℎh-th stable equilibrium and its closest right tipping point.

We observe that the server can only save on their payment by relying on the stability property of some self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium. Hence, if a dynamic has an equilibrium near 00 and few tipping points, then a server following the strategy in Theorem 13 would have to spend much less than the naive strategy of fully paying every client to be in the coalition. On the other hand, if the dynamic has a lot of tipping points or if the coalition requires a lot of new clients to move from a stable equilibrium to a higher tipping point, then following the payment strategy above does not vastly improve upon the naive strategy of paying every client. Specifically, we revisit the example where every value K𝐾K is a self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium.

Example: equilibrium at every point.

Revisit the example where the cost of joining is the same as the utility gain at every value K𝐾K, i.e., ∀K∈[M]:c​(K)=U​(K,n):for-all𝐾delimited-[]𝑀𝑐𝐾𝑈𝐾𝑛\forall K\in[M]:c(K)=U(K,n). By definition, every value K𝐾K is a self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium. If the initial expectation is 00, the server has to first pay the client with the lowest cost. At this point, the coalition has one client and has reached a tipping point. To move the dynamic towards a higher equilibrium, the server sends out another payment to the next client with the second lowest cost. This process stops when all clients have joined the coalition. Since the server has to pay for a new client every time, the total payment is P=∑i=1Mci𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑐𝑖P=\sum_{i=1}^{M}c_{i}.

Remark 14.

Since the clients who join the coalition also receive some utility from the joint model, we can also consider a more efficient payment scheme where the server only pays for the difference between a client’s cost and their expected utility gain. When all clients have the same number of local samples, they also have the same expected utility gain so the server would minimize their total payment by selecting clients with smaller costs first. This payment strategy is similar to our original strategy when the server has to pay for a client’s entire cost.

6.3 Payment in Utility Oracle Setting

We can generalize the payment structure above in the more general utility oracle setting when the initial coalition is empty. Similar to the mean estimation setting, at each time step, the server needs to rely on the stability property of self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium to reduce their total payment amount. That is, at each time step, the server wants to incentivize enough new clients to move the dynamic towards a higher self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium. Let client i𝑖i’s utility function be Ui​(n)subscript𝑈𝑖𝑛U_{i}(n) when the number of samples in the coalition is n𝑛n. Then, we can define the mapping h​(⋅)ℎ⋅h(\cdot) for this setting as the total number of samples from clients with higher expected utility gain than personal cost, i.e.,

h​(n)=∑i:Ui​(n)≥cini.ℎ𝑛subscript:𝑖subscript𝑈𝑖𝑛subscript𝑐𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖\displaystyle h(n)=\sum_{i:U_{i}(n)\geq c_{i}}n_{i}.

Suppose the initial coalition is empty, i.e., NS(0)=0superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑆00N_{S}^{(0)}=0 and let nn​e​x​tsubscript𝑛𝑛𝑒𝑥𝑡n_{next} be the next tipping point with h​(nn​e​x​t)≥nn​e​x​tℎsubscript𝑛𝑛𝑒𝑥𝑡subscript𝑛𝑛𝑒𝑥𝑡h(n_{next})\geq n_{next}, that is

nn​e​x​t=arg⁡min⁡{j:j>NS(t),h​(j)≥j}.subscript𝑛𝑛𝑒𝑥𝑡:𝑗formulae-sequence𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑆𝑡ℎ𝑗𝑗\displaystyle n_{next}=\arg\min\{j:j>N_{S}^{(t)},h(j)\geq j\}.

Then, our goal in the current time step is to move to nn​e​x​tsubscript𝑛𝑛𝑒𝑥𝑡n_{next} with the minimum payment. Let C¯={i:Uit​(NS)<ci}¯𝐶conditional-set𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑡subscript𝑁𝑆subscript𝑐𝑖\overline{C}=\{i:U_{i}^{t}(N_{S})<c_{i}\} be the set of clients who are not already in the coalition at the current time step t𝑡t. Then, we can solve an optimization problem to move to nn​e​x​tsubscript𝑛𝑛𝑒𝑥𝑡n_{next} as

min\displaystyle\min ∑i:i∈C¯xi⋅(ci−Ui(t)​(NS))subscript:𝑖𝑖¯𝐶⋅subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑐𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑡subscript𝑁𝑆\displaystyle\sum_{i:i\in\overline{C}}x_{i}\cdot(c_{i}-U_{i}^{(t)}(N_{S}))
s.t ∑i:i∈C¯xi⋅ni≥nn​e​x​t−NS(t).subscript:𝑖𝑖¯𝐶⋅subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑛𝑛𝑒𝑥𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑁𝑡𝑆\displaystyle\sum_{i:i\in\overline{C}}x_{i}\cdot n_{i}\geq n_{next}-N^{(t)}_{S}.

where xi∈{0,1}subscript𝑥𝑖01x_{i}\in\{0,1\}. This is a knapsack problem that can be solved by dynamic programming. This process is repeated until we have reached the highest self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium.

7 Discussion

We have initiated the study of clients’ behaviors in FL under a network effects game model, where each client’s participation decision changes as the network grows over time. We showed that whenever the entire population shares an expectation on the coalition size, we can characterize the dynamics of the client’s participation game for the mean estimation problem and a more general setting with a utility oracle. We identified self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium points, where the coalition after all clients have computed the best-response strategy matches the shared expectation. Moreover, we showed that without explicit intervention from the server, the client’s participation dynamic naturally converges to self-fulfilling expectation equilibria. Based on this characterization, we proposed a cost-efficient payment scheme that incentivizes clients so that the final coalition reaches a desirable equilibrium.

Our framework offers insights into clients’ participation dynamics in FL. A limitation of our work is that we did not consider more realistic learning problems, and also assumed assumed that all clients are trying to solve a global problem instead of a personalized approach. Despite these limitations, we believe that our work provides a meaningful contribution to the study of incentives in FL, and hope that continuing to understand client participation dynamics can lead to the design of explicit incentive mechanisms that induce desirable final outcomes in practical FL applications.

Finally, we can derive the utility gain of client i𝑖i from joining the coalition. Formally, the utility gain uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} for client i𝑖i is the difference in mean squared error between not joining the coalition (local MSE) and joining the coalition (coalition MSE):

Lemma 17 (Utility gain).

The utility gain of client i𝑖i from joining the coalition and using the shared model wSsubscript𝑤𝑆w_{S} is:

u​({nj}j∈S,i)=−1NS+1ni−(∑i≠jnj2−(NS−ni)2NS2−2​(NS−ni)NS)​σθ2𝑢subscriptsubscript𝑛𝑗𝑗𝑆𝑖1subscript𝑁𝑆1subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑗2superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑆subscript𝑛𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑆22subscript𝑁𝑆subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑁𝑆superscriptsubscript𝜎𝜃2u(\{n_{j}\}_{j\in S},i)=-\frac{1}{N_{S}}+\frac{1}{n_{i}}-\left(\frac{\sum_{i\neq j}n_{j}^{2}-(N_{S}-n_{i})^{2}}{N_{S}^{2}}-\frac{2(N_{S}-n_{i})}{N_{S}}\right)\sigma_{\theta}^{2} (38)

where NS=∑j∈Snjsubscript𝑁𝑆subscript𝑗𝑆subscript𝑛𝑗N_{S}=\sum_{j\in S}n_{j}.

Appendix B Appendix: FL in Mean Estimation Problem

In this example, suppose different clients have different costs of joining the coalition and the same number of local samples. W.L.O.G, we order the clients by their cost in ascending order. We also assume the cost of joining the coalition for the i𝑖i-th client is cmin+c​(i)subscript𝑐𝑐𝑖c_{\min}+c(i), where cminsubscript𝑐c_{\min} is a fixed positive cost for communication and c​(i)𝑐𝑖c(i) is a positive increasing function.

Since all clients joining the coalition will share the same model, we have u=ui𝑢subscript𝑢𝑖u=u_{i} for all i∈[M]𝑖delimited-[]𝑀i\in[M]. Let the equilibrium cost cmin>0subscript𝑐0c_{\min}>0 and the expected number of clients in coalition K𝐾K form a self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium, such that cmin+c​(K)=u​(K,n)subscript𝑐𝑐𝐾𝑢𝐾𝑛c_{\min}+c(K)=u(K,n).

We can write the new utility gain function for the i𝑖i-th client as:

f​(K,n,i)=u​(K,n)−c​(i)𝑓𝐾𝑛𝑖𝑢𝐾𝑛𝑐𝑖f(K,n,i)=u(K,n)-c(i) (45)

If all clients share a common belief that K𝐾K clients will join the coalition, then client i𝑖i would join the coalition if f​(K,n,i)≥cmin𝑓𝐾𝑛𝑖subscript𝑐f(K,n,i)\geq c_{\min}. Hence, if any client at all would join, the set of clients joining will be between 00 and K^^𝐾\hat{K}, where K^=inf{x∈ℝ:f​(K,n,i)≥cmin}^𝐾infimumconditional-set𝑥ℝ𝑓𝐾𝑛𝑖subscript𝑐\hat{K}=\inf\{x\in\mathbb{R}:f(K,n,i)\geq c_{\min}\}. Hence, to find the equilibrium client K^^𝐾\hat{K}, we proceed to solve the following equation:

f​(K,n,K^)=cmin𝑓𝐾𝑛^𝐾subscript𝑐f(K,n,\hat{K})=c_{\min} (46)

Fixing the number of local data n𝑛n, this is equivalent to

K^=f−1​(cmin)=c−1​(u​(K,n)−cmin)^𝐾superscript𝑓1subscript𝑐superscript𝑐1𝑢𝐾𝑛subscript𝑐\hat{K}=f^{-1}(c_{\min})=c^{-1}(u(K,n)-c_{\min}) (47)

B.1 Existence of an equilibrium

Let hℎh be the mapping from K𝐾K to K^^𝐾\hat{K}, meaning that when all clients share a common belief K𝐾K clients will join the coalition, then the number of clients willing to join will be K^=h​(K)^𝐾ℎ𝐾\hat{K}=h(K).

Proof of Corollary 6

Suppose there exists K𝐾K with h​(K)≥Kℎ𝐾𝐾h(K)\geq K, we prove that there must exist K∗≥Ksuperscript𝐾𝐾K^{*}\geq K with h​(K∗)=K∗ℎsuperscript𝐾superscript𝐾h(K^{*})=K^{*}. First if h​(K)=Kℎ𝐾𝐾h(K)=K, we have found K∗=Ksuperscript𝐾𝐾K^{*}=K. So we only need to consider the case h​(K)>Kℎ𝐾𝐾h(K)>K. When h​(K)>Kℎ𝐾𝐾h(K)>K, we prove the following claim: we can find K′≥Ksuperscript𝐾′𝐾K^{\prime}\geq K with

h​(K′)≥K′​ and ​h​(h​(K′))≤h​(K′).ℎsuperscript𝐾′superscript𝐾′ and ℎℎsuperscript𝐾′ℎsuperscript𝐾′\displaystyle h(K^{\prime})\geq K^{\prime}\text{ and }h(h(K^{\prime}))\leq h(K^{\prime}). (48)

We first set K′=Ksuperscript𝐾′𝐾K^{\prime}=K and check whether K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime} satisfies the condition (48). If the condition is not satisfied, we set K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime} to be its function value h​(K′)ℎsuperscript𝐾′h(K^{\prime}) and iterate until the condition is satisfied. We can prove that K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime} must strictly increase at each iteration. This is because at the beginning we have h​(K′)>K′ℎsuperscript𝐾′superscript𝐾′h(K^{\prime})>K^{\prime} and we only continue the iteration when h​(h​(K′))>h​(K′)ℎℎsuperscript𝐾′ℎsuperscript𝐾′h(h(K^{\prime}))>h(K^{\prime}). Therefore, the iteration must end because K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime} must strictly increase at each iteration and the value of K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime} cannot exceed the number of clients M𝑀M. And when the iteration ends, we either find K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime} with (48), or we find an equilibrium K′=h​(K′)=Msuperscript𝐾′ℎsuperscript𝐾′𝑀K^{\prime}=h(K^{\prime})=M.

Finally, we prove that for K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime} with (48), we have h​(h​(K′))=h​(K′)ℎℎsuperscript𝐾′ℎsuperscript𝐾′h(h(K^{\prime}))=h(K^{\prime}) so we find an equilibrium K∗=h​(K′)superscript𝐾ℎsuperscript𝐾′K^{*}=h(K^{\prime}). We use the fact that h​(⋅)ℎ⋅h(\cdot) must be a non-decreasing function. So we have h​(h​(K′))≥h​(K′)ℎℎsuperscript𝐾′ℎsuperscript𝐾′h(h(K^{\prime}))\geq h(K^{\prime}) for h​(K′)≥K′ℎsuperscript𝐾′superscript𝐾′h(K^{\prime})\geq K^{\prime}. Together with h​(h​(K′))≤h​(K′)ℎℎsuperscript𝐾′ℎsuperscript𝐾′h(h(K^{\prime}))\leq h(K^{\prime}) in (48), h​(h​(K′))=h​(K′)ℎℎsuperscript𝐾′ℎsuperscript𝐾′h(h(K^{\prime}))=h(K^{\prime}).

This result can also be interpreted as, every time K^^𝐾\hat{K} goes above K𝐾K, we must have an equilibrium.

Equivalent Sufficient Condition

In our formulation, the function h​(K)ℎ𝐾h(K) is a composition of the cost function c​(i)𝑐𝑖c(i) and the utility function u​(K,n)𝑢𝐾𝑛u(K,n). Formally, we have h​(K)=c−1​(u​(K,n))ℎ𝐾superscript𝑐1𝑢𝐾𝑛h(K)=c^{-1}(u(K,n)). Note that we assume the cost function c​(i)𝑐𝑖c(i) is monotonically increasing with regard to the client index i𝑖i. Hence, we can apply c(.)c(.) to both side of the sufficient condition in Corollary 6 and get:

h​(K)ℎ𝐾\displaystyle h(K) ≥Kabsent𝐾\displaystyle\geq K
⇔c−1​(u​(K,n))iffabsentsuperscript𝑐1𝑢𝐾𝑛\displaystyle\iff c^{-1}(u(K,n)) ≥Kabsent𝐾\displaystyle\geq K
⇔c​(c−1​(u​(K,n)))iffabsent𝑐superscript𝑐1𝑢𝐾𝑛\displaystyle\iff c(c^{-1}(u(K,n))) ≥c​(K)absent𝑐𝐾\displaystyle\geq c(K)
⇔u​(K,n)iffabsent𝑢𝐾𝑛\displaystyle\iff u(K,n) ≥c​(K)absent𝑐𝐾\displaystyle\geq c(K)

Hence, the sufficient condition for an equilibrium to happen can be rewritten as: a self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium exists as long as there exists some K𝐾K with u​(K,n)≥c​(K)𝑢𝐾𝑛𝑐𝐾u(K,n)\geq c(K).

Then, in the special case above, there exists only one non-trivial stable equilibrium at K=M𝐾𝑀K=M.

Proof of Corollary 7

We follow the same analysis as in the proof of Corollary 6 and apply the definition of stable equilibrium in Definition 3.

Proof of Corollary 8

Suppose that the initial expectation K𝐾K is a self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium. We want to look at what happens when there is a slight perturbation in the actual number of people joining the coalition K^=K^𝐾𝐾\hat{K}=K. There are two cases:

  • •

    If K𝐾K is a stable equilibrium: By definition, any slight perturbation to K^^𝐾\hat{K} will make the expectation converges back to K𝐾K.

  • •

    If K𝐾K is not a stable equilibrium: When the actual outcome K^^𝐾\hat{K} changes slightly and the shared expectation K𝐾K stays the same, the utility gain u​(K,n)𝑢𝐾𝑛u(K,n) does not changes. We look at how the cost of joining c​(K^)𝑐^𝐾c(\hat{K}) changes when a client leaves or when a new client joins the coalition.

    • –

      If the K+1𝐾1K+1-th client joins the coalition: the cost of joining for the K+1𝐾1K+1-th client is c​(K+1)<u​(K,n)𝑐𝐾1𝑢𝐾𝑛c(K+1)<u(K,n). Since we assume the cost function is monotonically increasing (non-decreasing), the fact that the K+1𝐾1K+1-th client joining does not change the opt-in/opt-out decision of all previous clients. Also, since the utility function u​(K,n)𝑢𝐾𝑛u(K,n) is non-decreasing, then u​(K+1,n)>u​(K,n)>c​(K+1)𝑢𝐾1𝑛𝑢𝐾𝑛𝑐𝐾1u(K+1,n)>u(K,n)>c(K+1). Hence, the shared expectation will become K+1𝐾1K+1. When the next client K+2𝐾2K+2 decides whether to join the coalition, they will compare their personal cost c​(K+2)𝑐𝐾2c(K+2) to the new shared expectation K+1𝐾1K+1. This process continues until we reach a new equilibrium K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime}.

    • –

      If the K𝐾K-th client leaves the coalition: the K𝐾K-th client leaves the coalition when c​(K)>u​(K,n)𝑐𝐾𝑢𝐾𝑛c(K)>u(K,n). Since the cost function is monotonically increasing, we have c​(K+1)>c​(K)>u​(K,n)𝑐𝐾1𝑐𝐾𝑢𝐾𝑛c(K+1)>c(K)>u(K,n). Hence, all clients from K+1𝐾1K+1 to M𝑀M will not join the coalition. Then, the maximum number of clients in a coalition is less than K𝐾K and there is downward pressure on the expectation. Suppose the expectation is now reduced by 111, i.e. the utility gain is u​(K−1,n)𝑢𝐾1𝑛u(K-1,n). There are two cases. If the personal cost of client K−1𝐾1K-1 is less than the utility, i.e. c​(K−1)<u​(K−1,n)𝑐𝐾1𝑢𝐾1𝑛c(K-1)<u(K-1,n), then we arrive at a self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium and no other clients would leave the coalition. Otherwise, if we have c​(K−1)>u​(K−1,n)𝑐𝐾1𝑢𝐾1𝑛c(K-1)>u(K-1,n), then the K−1𝐾1K-1-th client would also leave the coalition. The expectation goes into a downward spiral until we reach some equilibrium K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime} such that c​(K′)<u​(K′,n)𝑐superscript𝐾′𝑢superscript𝐾′𝑛c(K^{\prime})<u(K^{\prime},n) and c​(K′+1)>u​(K′+1,n)𝑐superscript𝐾′1𝑢superscript𝐾′1𝑛c(K^{\prime}+1)>u(K^{\prime}+1,n).

Behavior of tipping points

From the previous analysis, we observe that a slight perturbation to the actual outcome at the tipping point (unstable equilibrium) will lead the expectation to move toward either a higher or lower equilibrium. If the coalition settles at a new equilibrium that is also a tipping point, then additional perturbations to the actual outcome will move the expectation to another equilibrium. This behavior only stops when the shared expectation reaches a stable equilibrium.

Proof of Corollary 9

Suppose there exists a number of samples in the coalition h​(K)≥Kℎ𝐾𝐾h(K)\geq K, we prove that there must exist some equilibrium K∗≥Ksuperscript𝐾𝐾K^{*}\geq K with h​(K∗)=K∗ℎsuperscript𝐾superscript𝐾h(K^{*})=K^{*}. If h​(K)=Kℎ𝐾𝐾h(K)=K, then K∗=Ksuperscript𝐾𝐾K^{*}=K is the equilibrium. Else, if h​(K)>Kℎ𝐾𝐾h(K)>K, we can find some K′≥Ksuperscript𝐾′𝐾K^{\prime}\geq K with

h​(K′)≥K′andh​(h​(K′))≤h​(K′)formulae-sequenceℎsuperscript𝐾′superscript𝐾′andℎℎsuperscript𝐾′ℎsuperscript𝐾′h(K^{\prime})\geq K^{\prime}\quad\text{and}\quad h(h(K^{\prime}))\leq h(K^{\prime}) (49)

First, we set K′=Ksuperscript𝐾′𝐾K^{\prime}=K and check whether K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime} satisfies the condition eq. 49. If the condition is not satisfied, we set K′=h​(K′)superscript𝐾′ℎsuperscript𝐾′K^{\prime}=h(K^{\prime}) and repeat the process to find h​(h​(K′))ℎℎsuperscript𝐾′h(h(K^{\prime})). Initially, we have h​(K′)>K′ℎsuperscript𝐾′superscript𝐾′h(K^{\prime})>K^{\prime}. By design, the inferred number of samples in the coalition t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime} is always larger than or equal to the expectation K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime}. For each client in the inferred coalition, they can check if their utility gain is larger than the cost of joining. The clients with a higher cost than utility gain will not be in the coalition. There are two cases:

  • •

    If h​(h​(K′))>h​(K′)ℎℎsuperscript𝐾′ℎsuperscript𝐾′h(h(K^{\prime}))>h(K^{\prime}): then we continue for another iteration.

  • •

    Otherwise, if h​(h​(K))≤h​(K′)ℎℎ𝐾ℎsuperscript𝐾′h(h(K))\leq h(K^{\prime}): then we have found the K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime} that satisfy condition Equation 49.

Since there are M𝑀M clients in the population, we know that there are at most NMsubscript𝑁𝑀N_{M} samples in the coalition (where NMsubscript𝑁𝑀N_{M} is the total number of samples for every client in the population). Since we only continue the iterations when we have h​(x)>xℎ𝑥𝑥h(x)>x for some number of samples x𝑥x, we know that the iteration is guaranteed to end when every client join the coalition. Hence, we can always find some K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime} that satisfy Equation 49.

To complete the proof, we prove that for a number of samples K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime} that satisfy Equation 49, we have h​(h​(K′))=h​(K′)ℎℎsuperscript𝐾′ℎsuperscript𝐾′h(h(K^{\prime}))=h(K^{\prime}) so we have found an equilibrium K∗=h​(K′)superscript𝐾ℎsuperscript𝐾′K^{*}=h(K^{\prime}). Since the h​(⋅)ℎ⋅h(\cdot) function is a non-decreasing function by assumption, we have h​(h​(K′))≥h​(K′)ℎℎsuperscript𝐾′ℎsuperscript𝐾′h(h(K^{\prime}))\geq h(K^{\prime}) for h​(K′)≥K′ℎsuperscript𝐾′superscript𝐾′h(K^{\prime})\geq K^{\prime}. Combine this fact with Equation 49, we have h​(h​(K′))=h​(K′)ℎℎsuperscript𝐾′ℎsuperscript𝐾′h(h(K^{\prime}))=h(K^{\prime}).

Necessary condition: non-decreasing h​(⋅)ℎ⋅h(\cdot)

Let K𝐾K and K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime} be two expected number of samples in the coalition such that K>K′𝐾superscript𝐾′K>K^{\prime}. Also, let S𝑆S and S′superscript𝑆′S^{\prime} denote the coalition with expectation K𝐾K and K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime}, respectively. Observe that since K>K′𝐾superscript𝐾′K>K^{\prime}, if a client i𝑖i is in the inferred coalition with expectation K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime}, they would also be in the inferred coalition with expectation K𝐾K since their utility gain in S𝑆S is larger than utility gain in S′superscript𝑆′S^{\prime} (which is larger than their personal cost). For some clients i𝑖i in the inferred coalition Sinferred′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′inferredS^{\prime}_{\text{inferred}} with expectation K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime}, there are two cases to consider:

  • •

    If ui≥cisubscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝑐𝑖u_{i}\geq c_{i}, then client i𝑖i would be in the coalition S′superscript𝑆′S^{\prime}. Since the ordering is maintained, client i𝑖i would also be in coalition S𝑆S with expectation K𝐾K.

  • •

    If ui<cisubscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝑐𝑖u_{i}<c_{i}, then client i𝑖i would not be in the coalition S′superscript𝑆′S^{\prime}. Since we order the clients in descending order of z𝑧z, all other clients j∈[i,M]𝑗𝑖𝑀j\in[i,M] would also not join the coalition S′superscript𝑆′S^{\prime}. However, since K>K𝐾𝐾K>K, the expected utility gain for joining with expectation K𝐾K is greater than the expected utility gain for joining with expectation K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime}. Hence, there is still a possibility that client i𝑖i would join coalition S𝑆S with expectation K𝐾K.

Therefore, the number of clients in coalition S𝑆S is always greater than or equal to the number of clients in coalition S′superscript𝑆′S^{\prime}. Similarly, the number of samples in S𝑆S is greater than or equal to the number of samples in S′superscript𝑆′S^{\prime}. Hence, h​(K)ℎ𝐾h(K) is a non-decreasing function in K𝐾K.

Proof of Corollary 10

Suppose that the expected number of samples in the coalition K𝐾K is a self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium. In the following paragraph, we describe the network dynamic when there is a slight perturbation to the actual number of samples in the coalition. Note that by definition of self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium, initially we have K^=K^𝐾𝐾\hat{K}=K. There are two cases to consider:

  • •

    If K𝐾K is a stable equilibrium: by definition of stable equilibrium, any slight perturbation to the actual number of samples K^^𝐾\hat{K} will lead the expectation converges back to K𝐾K.

  • •

    If K𝐾K is a tipping point: When the actual number of samples K^^𝐾\hat{K} changes, the client can update their shared belief and observe that the utility gain is also changed. According to our assumption, the cost of each client is a random variable independent of how many clients are actually in the coalition. Hence, there could be some clients that change their decision based on the updated utility gain.

Specifically, we can take a look at the dynamic at the tipping point when there are ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon additional samples or fewer samples in the coalition:

  • •

    If there are ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 more samples in the coalition from some client j𝑗j joining: the cost of being in the coalition for a client i∈S𝑖𝑆i\in S is ci<u​(K,i)subscript𝑐𝑖𝑢𝐾𝑖c_{i}<u(K,i). By assumption, the utility gain function is monotonically non-decreasing. Hence, having more samples in the coalition would increase the utility gain for all clients i∈S𝑖𝑆i\in S. Consider a client j𝑗j who was not previously in coalition S𝑆S has index j>i:∀i∈S:𝑗𝑖for-all𝑖𝑆j>i:\forall i\in S, their overall gain from joining the coalition zj<zi:∀i∈S:subscript𝑧𝑗subscript𝑧𝑖for-all𝑖𝑆z_{j}<z_{i}:\forall i\in S. Hence, if client j𝑗j join the coalition S𝑆S, then all other clients i∈S𝑖𝑆i\in S would still stay in coalition S𝑆S. Then, the shared expectation would now be K+ϵ𝐾italic-ϵK+\epsilon, and the expected utility gain for all clients is increased. A new client ℓℓ\ell who is not in S𝑆S would compare this new utility gain u​(K+ϵ,ℓ)𝑢𝐾italic-ϵℓu(K+\epsilon,\ell) with their personal cost cℓsubscript𝑐ℓc_{\ell} and join if u​(K+ϵ,ℓ)≥cℓ𝑢𝐾italic-ϵℓsubscript𝑐ℓu(K+\epsilon,\ell)\geq c_{\ell}. This process will continue until the population reaches a stable equilibrium, where having slightly more data does not change the number of clients and samples in the coalition.

  • •

    If there are ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 more samples in the coalition from some client j𝑗j joining and some other client ℓ∈Sℓ𝑆\ell\in S leaving: since we rank the clients by their personal gain zisubscript𝑧𝑖z_{i} with arbitrary tie-breaking, there could be a case where a client ℓ∈Sℓ𝑆\ell\in S and client j∉S𝑗𝑆j\notin S have zℓ=zjsubscript𝑧ℓsubscript𝑧𝑗z_{\ell}=z_{j} and nℓ<njsubscript𝑛ℓsubscript𝑛𝑗n_{\ell}<n_{j}. Then, we can replace client ℓℓ\ell by client j𝑗j in the coalition and gain ϵ=nj−nℓitalic-ϵsubscript𝑛𝑗subscript𝑛ℓ\epsilon=n_{j}-n_{\ell} samples. The expected utility gain from joining the coalition increases since there are samples in S𝑆S. Since the expected number of samples changes, the ordering of clients in the population also changes. However, similar to our previous argument in the necessary condition, the clients who are already in the coalition should still be in the coalition after having more samples. The clients who are not in the clients can recompute their expected utility gain and decide whether to join the coalition or not. Since K𝐾K is a tipping point, there is at least one client who is now willing to join the coalition. This process only end when the population converges to a stable equilibrium, where having more samples does not change the composition of the coalition.

  • •

    If there are ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon fewer samples in the coalition from some client j𝑗j leaving: since we order clients by their personal gain zisubscript𝑧𝑖z_{i}, all other clients ℓ∈[j,M]ℓ𝑗𝑀\ell\in[j,M] will not join the coalition. Then, the number of samples in the coalition is fewer than K𝐾K, and the expected utility gain is reduced. All clients in the population can recompute their utility gain according to the updated number of samples. Clients will keep leaving the coalition if their utility gain is less than their personal cost until the population is at a stable equilibrium.

Appendix C Utility Oracle Appendix

In the following analysis, we assume a more general form of the utility function. Let Ui(t)=u​(NS(t))superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑡𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑆𝑡U_{i}^{(t)}=u(N_{S}^{(t)}) be the utility gain for a client i𝑖i at round t𝑡t if client i𝑖i is in the coalition with NS(t)superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑆𝑡N_{S}^{(t)} samples. This formulation of utility only depends on the size of the coalition and the opt-in/opt-out decisions of other clients in the coalition. Since all clients know the true utility regardless of whether or not they join the coalition, there is no longer a need for the population to form an expectation over the size of the coalition. In this setting, the expected utility for time step t𝑡t is the oracle utility of the previous time step t−1𝑡1t-1, i.e., 𝔼​[Ui(t)]=Ui(t−1)𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑡1\mathbb{E}[U_{i}^{(t)}]=U_{i}^{(t-1)}.

Example: Participation Dynamic with Utility Oracle

Suppose there are four clients in the population whose local sample sizes follow a uniform distribution. That is, if the total number of samples in the coalition is N𝑁N, then client 111 has 1/N1𝑁1/N samples, client 222 has 2/N2𝑁2/N samples, client 333 has 3/N3𝑁3/N samples, and client 444 has 4/N4𝑁4/N samples. Furthermore, assume that each client i𝑖i has a fixed cost cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i} and 0≈c1≤c2≤c3≤c40subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2subscript𝑐3subscript𝑐40\approx c_{1}\leq c_{2}\leq c_{3}\leq c_{4}.

  • •

    First coalition is S={1,4}𝑆14S=\{1,4\}: In the beginning, assume that client 111 and 444 are in the coalition: S={1,4}𝑆14S=\{1,4\} with 5/N5𝑁5/N samples. The oracle utility at time step 111 is U(1)​(5/N)superscript𝑈15𝑁U^{(1)}(5/N). Suppose at the start of the time step 222, client 444 observes that U(1)​(5/N)<c4superscript𝑈15𝑁subscript𝑐4U^{(1)}(5/N)<c_{4} and decides to leave. We have three events that can happen at this step:

    1. 1.

      Both client 222 and 333 join: If client 222 and 333 observe that the expected utility from previous time step U(1)​(5/N)≥c3>c2superscript𝑈15𝑁subscript𝑐3subscript𝑐2U^{(1)}(5/N)\geq c_{3}>c_{2}, then they will join the coalition. Then, at the end of time step 222, the coalition is S={1,2,3}𝑆123S=\{1,2,3\} with utility U(2)​(6/N)superscript𝑈26𝑁U^{(2)}(6/N). At time step 333, if client 444 observes that U(2)​(6/N)<c4superscript𝑈26𝑁subscript𝑐4U^{(2)}(6/N)<c_{4}, then they would still opt-out of the coalition. Otherwise, if we have U(2)​(6/N)≥c4superscript𝑈26𝑁subscript𝑐4U^{(2)}(6/N)\geq c_{4}, then client 444 would join the coalition instead. For clients 1,2121,2 and 333, they do not leave the coalition since U(2)​(6/N)≥U(1)​(5/N)≥c3>c2>c1superscript𝑈26𝑁superscript𝑈15𝑁subscript𝑐3subscript𝑐2subscript𝑐1U^{(2)}(6/N)\geq U^{(1)}(5/N)\geq c_{3}>c_{2}>c_{1}.
