    2. 2.

      Only client 222 joins: If we have c3>U(1)​(5/N)≥c2subscript𝑐3superscript𝑈15𝑁subscript𝑐2c_{3}>U^{(1)}(5/N)\geq c_{2}, then only client 222 would join the coalition at time step 222. At the end of time step 222, the coalition is S={1,2}𝑆12S=\{1,2\} with utility U(2)​(3/N)superscript𝑈23𝑁U^{(2)}(3/N). At time step 333, we have U(2)​(3/N)<U(1)​(5/N)<c3<c4superscript𝑈23𝑁superscript𝑈15𝑁subscript𝑐3subscript𝑐4U^{(2)}(3/N)<U^{(1)}(5/N)<c_{3}<c_{4}, so client 333 and 444 would not join the coalition. If client 222 observes that U(2)<c2≤c2superscript𝑈2subscript𝑐2subscript𝑐2U^{(2)}<c_{2}\leq c_{2}, then client 222 would also leave the coalition. At the end of time step 333, the coalition is S={1}𝑆1S=\{1\} with utility U(3)​(1/N)superscript𝑈31𝑁U^{(3)}(1/N). Otherwise, if we have U(2)>c2superscript𝑈2subscript𝑐2U^{(2)}>c_{2}, then client 222 would still stay in the coalition. In this case, the coalition utility at the end of time step 333 is U(3)​(3/N)=U(2)​(3/N)superscript𝑈33𝑁superscript𝑈23𝑁U^{(3)}(3/N)=U^{(2)}(3/N) and we have arrived at an equilibrium.

    3. 3.

      No other client joins: If we have c3>c2>U(1)​(5/N)subscript𝑐3subscript𝑐2superscript𝑈15𝑁c_{3}>c_{2}>U^{(1)}(5/N), then no client would join the coalition. The coalition at the end of day 222 is S={1}𝑆1S=\{1\} with utility U(2)​(1/N)superscript𝑈21𝑁U^{(2)}(1/N). Due to the monotonicity assumption, we have U(2)​(1/N)≤U(1)​(5/N)<c2<c3<c4superscript𝑈21𝑁superscript𝑈15𝑁subscript𝑐2subscript𝑐3subscript𝑐4U^{(2)}(1/N)\leq U^{(1)}(5/N)<c_{2}<c_{3}<c_{4}, and no other clients would join the coalition. Regardless of the client 111’s decision, we will arrive at an equilibrium.

    Therefore, in any of the aforementioned events, we will arrive at an equilibrium.

In our prior analysis, we use h​(K)ℎ𝐾h(K) to denote the actual size of the coalition when the shared size is K𝐾K. When the clients can observe the oracle utility, they adjust the shared expectation for time step t𝑡t to be the oracle utility from time step t−1𝑡1t-1. Hence, if K𝐾K is the coalition’s size at round t𝑡t, then we use h​(K)ℎ𝐾h(K) to denote the size of the coalition at round t+1𝑡1t+1.

Proof of Theorem 12

Suppose there exists an arbitrary coalition containing K1subscript𝐾1K_{1} samples formed by some clients at time step t=1𝑡1t=1. In the following analysis, we show the iterative process for the dynamic to converge to a self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium.

At time step 222:

Suppose there exist some clients i∈S𝑖𝑆i\in S with Ui(1)​(K1)<c1subscriptsuperscript𝑈1𝑖subscript𝐾1subscript𝑐1U^{(1)}_{i}(K_{1})<c_{1}. Then, at the start of time step 222, these clients would leave the coalition with NL(2)≥0subscriptsuperscript𝑁2𝐿0N^{(2)}_{L}\geq 0 samples. If no clients leave the coalition at this point, then NL(2)=0subscriptsuperscript𝑁2𝐿0N^{(2)}_{L}=0, otherwise NL(2)>0subscriptsuperscript𝑁2𝐿0N^{(2)}_{L}>0. At the same time, some other clients j∈J2:Uj(1)​(K1)>cj:𝑗subscript𝐽2superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑗1subscript𝐾1subscript𝑐𝑗j\in J_{2}:U_{j}^{(1)}(K_{1})>c_{j} would join the coalition with NJ(2)≥0superscriptsubscript𝑁𝐽20N_{J}^{(2)}\geq 0 samples. Then, at the end of time step 222, the total size of coalition S𝑆S is K2=K1−NL(2)+NJ(1)subscript𝐾2subscript𝐾1superscriptsubscript𝑁𝐿2superscriptsubscript𝑁𝐽1K_{2}=K_{1}-N_{L}^{(2)}+N_{J}^{(1)}.

At time step 333:

At the beginning of time step 333, clients i∈S𝑖𝑆i\in S first re-evaluate their opt-in decision by comparing their cost with the expected utility.

  • •

    If we have K2≥K1subscript𝐾2subscript𝐾1K_{2}\geq K_{1}, then by monotonicity assumption, we have ∀i∈S:Ui(2)​(K2)≥Ui(1)​(K1)>ci:for-all𝑖𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖2subscript𝐾2superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖1subscript𝐾1subscript𝑐𝑖\forall i\in S:U_{i}^{(2)}(K_{2})\geq U_{i}^{(1)}(K_{1})>c_{i}. That is, all clients who are already in the coalition gain more utility by staying and not changing their decision. Hence, the size of the coalition would not decrease at time step 333.

  • •

    If we have K2<K1subscript𝐾2subscript𝐾1K_{2}<K_{1}, then by monotonicity assumption, there are some clients i𝑖i who will leave the coalition due to insufficient utility gain: ∃i∈S:Ui(2)​(K2)≤ci<Ui(1)​(K1):𝑖𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖2subscript𝐾2subscript𝑐𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖1subscript𝐾1\exists i\in S:U_{i}^{(2)}(K_{2})\leq c_{i}<U_{i}^{(1)}(K_{1}). Note that for other clients j∉S𝑗𝑆j\notin S, they observe Uj(2)​(K2)<Uj(1)​(K1)<cjsuperscriptsubscript𝑈𝑗2subscript𝐾2superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑗1subscript𝐾1subscript𝑐𝑗U_{j}^{(2)}(K_{2})<U_{j}^{(1)}(K_{1})<c_{j} so they would still not join the coalition at this time step. Hence, the size of the coalition would decrease at time step 333.

Observe that if we have K2≥K1subscript𝐾2subscript𝐾1K_{2}\geq K_{1}, then the size of the coalition does not decrease at time step 333, i.e., K3≥K2subscript𝐾3subscript𝐾2K_{3}\geq K_{2}. On the other hand, if K2<K1subscript𝐾2subscript𝐾1K_{2}<K_{1}, then we will have K3<K2subscript𝐾3subscript𝐾2K_{3}<K_{2}.

Induction hypothesis: If Kt<Kt−1subscript𝐾𝑡subscript𝐾𝑡1K_{t}<K_{t-1}, then Kt+1≤Ktsubscript𝐾𝑡1subscript𝐾𝑡K_{t+1}\leq K_{t}. Otherwise, if Kt≥Kt−1subscript𝐾𝑡subscript𝐾𝑡1K_{t}\geq K_{t-1}, then Kt+1≥Ktsubscript𝐾𝑡1subscript𝐾𝑡K_{t+1}\geq K_{t}.

Show that the induction hypothesis holds for time step t+1𝑡1t+1:

  • •

    If the number of samples in the coalition decreases at time step t𝑡t, then we have Kt<Kt−1subscript𝐾𝑡subscript𝐾𝑡1K_{t}<K_{t-1}. By monotonicity assumption, for all clients i∈[M]𝑖delimited-[]𝑀i\in[M], we have Ui(t)​(Kt)<Ui(t−1)​(Kt−1)superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑡subscript𝐾𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑡1subscript𝐾𝑡1U_{i}^{(t)}(K_{t})<U_{i}^{(t-1)}(K_{t-1}). Then at the start of time step t+1𝑡1t+1, the clients who have not joined the coalition in the previous time step would also not join at time step t+1𝑡1t+1 due to insufficient utility gain. On the other hand, clients j∈S𝑗𝑆j\in S who are in the coalition at time step t𝑡t might leave the coalition if Uj(t−1)​(Kt−1)≥cj>Uj(t)superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑗𝑡1subscript𝐾𝑡1subscript𝑐𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑗𝑡U_{j}^{(t-1)}(K_{t-1})\geq c_{j}>U_{j}^{(t)}. Hence, the size of the coalition would either decrease at time step t+1𝑡1t+1 or stay the same (where we have found an equilibrium).

  • •

    If the number of samples in the coalition does not decrease at time step t𝑡t, then we have Kt≥Kt−1subscript𝐾𝑡subscript𝐾𝑡1K_{t}\geq K_{t-1}. By monotonicity assumption, for all clients i∈[M]𝑖delimited-[]𝑀i\in[M], we have Ui(t)​(Kt)≥Ui(t−1)​(Kt−1)superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑡subscript𝐾𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑡1subscript𝐾𝑡1U_{i}^{(t)}(K_{t})\geq U_{i}^{(t-1)}(K_{t-1}). Hence, at the start of time step t+1𝑡1t+1, all clients j∈S𝑗𝑆j\in S who are already in the coalition gain more utility by staying and not changing their decision. Also, there could be some clients ℓℓ\ell previously not in the coalition with Uℓ(t)​(Kt)≥cℓ≥Uℓ(t−1)​(Kt−1)superscriptsubscript𝑈ℓ𝑡subscript𝐾𝑡subscript𝑐ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝑈ℓ𝑡1subscript𝐾𝑡1U_{\ell}^{(t)}(K_{t})\geq c_{\ell}\geq U_{\ell}^{(t-1)}(K_{t-1}) who will join at time step t+1𝑡1t+1. Thus, the size of the coalition would either stay the same (where we have found an equilibrium) or increase at time step t+1𝑡1t+1.

This iterated process will continue until either we have the same coalition size in two consecutive rounds (which is a self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium) or we have all clients (or no clients) in the coalition. Therefore, the dynamic with utility oracle will converge to a self-fulfilling expectation equilibrium.

Remark 19.

Compared to our previous analysis of the heterogeneous setting in a network effect game, we no longer need to form an inferred coalition to form an expectation over the utility gain from joining. Since all clients, regardless of being in the coalition or not, know the true utility, we can instead start the dynamic with any arbitrary coalition of clients. Then, other clients in the population can start making decisions based on the oracle utility.

Appendix D Appendix: Incentive with Payment

Proof of Theorem 13

Initially, the shared expectation is there are no clients in the coalition. If the server does not send any payment message, then there is no client willing to join the coalition and the dynamic is stuck at the trivial stable equilibrium of 00. On the other hand, if the server sends payments to K0subscript𝐾0K_{0} clients, where K0subscript𝐾0K_{0} is between 00 and the first tipping point, then the dynamic would converge back to the trivial equilibrium of 00. Hence, to move the dynamic toward a higher equilibrium, the server needs to first send payments to K0subscript𝐾0K_{0} clients, where S={i}i=1K0𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑖1subscript𝐾0S=\{i\}_{i=1}^{K_{0}} is the first tipping point. To minimize the total payment needed, the server can order the population by their cost in ascending order and send payment to the first K0subscript𝐾0K_{0} clients with the smallest costs.

By definition, once the population has reached the first tipping point, the expected number of clients is equal to the actual number of clients in the coalition. Hence, no new client would join the coalition without external incentives. At a tipping point, if there is an extra client joining the coalition then the dynamic would move toward a higher equilibrium. Thus, the server would send a payment message to the client with the smallest cost who is not in S𝑆S. With this new client joining, the expected utility gain for the next round is increased, and new clients would keep joining the coalition until the dynamic has reached a new equilibrium. If this new equilibrium is also a tipping point, then the server only needs to pay for one new client to join the coalition. On the other hand, if the new equilibrium is a stable equilibrium, then the server needs to either pay K1subscript𝐾1K_{1} new clients, where K1subscript𝐾1K_{1} is the difference between this stable equilibrium and the next tipping point, or 00 if the coalition has reached the largest stable equilibrium. The number of paid clients at this step cannot be less than K1subscript𝐾1K_{1} as the dynamic would converge back to the stable equilibrium. This payment schedule would continue until the dynamic converges to the largest equilibrium. The total amount of payment is the sum of payments sent by the server at each step. In the case where there are only two stable equilibria (the trivial equilibria at 00 and at M𝑀M), the total amount of payment scales linearly with the number of tipping points in the dynamic.

Incentive with payment when there exists a utility oracle:

Note that we assume the expected utility when there exists an oracle only depends on the number of samples in the coalition. Let client i𝑖i’s utility function be Ui​(n)subscript𝑈𝑖𝑛U_{i}(n) when the number of samples is n𝑛n. Then we can define h​(⋅)ℎ⋅h(\cdot) function as

h​(n)=∑i:Ui​(n)≥cini.ℎ𝑛subscript:𝑖subscript𝑈𝑖𝑛subscript𝑐𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖\displaystyle h(n)=\sum_{i:U_{i}(n)\geq c_{i}}n_{i}.

Suppose we start with n~=0~𝑛0\tilde{n}=0, let nn​e​x​tsubscript𝑛𝑛𝑒𝑥𝑡n_{next} be the next tipping point with h​(nn​e​x​t)≥nn​e​x​tℎsubscript𝑛𝑛𝑒𝑥𝑡subscript𝑛𝑛𝑒𝑥𝑡h(n_{next})\geq n_{next}, that is

nn​e​x​t=arg⁡min⁡{j:j>n~,h​(j)≥j}.subscript𝑛𝑛𝑒𝑥𝑡:𝑗formulae-sequence𝑗~𝑛ℎ𝑗𝑗\displaystyle n_{next}=\arg\min\{j:j>\tilde{n},h(j)\geq j\}.

then our goal in the current step is to move to nn​e​x​tsubscript𝑛𝑛𝑒𝑥𝑡n_{next} with a minimum payment. Let C¯={i:Ui​(n~)<ci}¯𝐶conditional-set𝑖subscript𝑈𝑖~𝑛subscript𝑐𝑖\overline{C}=\{i:U_{i}(\tilde{n})<c_{i}\} be the clients who are not in the coalition yet. Then we can solve an optimization problem to move to nn​e​x​tsubscript𝑛𝑛𝑒𝑥𝑡n_{next} as

min\displaystyle\min ∑i:i∈C¯xi⋅(ci−Ui​(n~))subscript:𝑖𝑖¯𝐶⋅subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑐𝑖subscript𝑈𝑖~𝑛\displaystyle\sum_{i:i\in\overline{C}}x_{i}\cdot(c_{i}-U_{i}(\tilde{n}))
s.t ∑i:i∈C¯xi⋅ni≥nn​e​x​t−n~.subscript:𝑖𝑖¯𝐶⋅subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑛𝑛𝑒𝑥𝑡~𝑛\displaystyle\sum_{i:i\in\overline{C}}x_{i}\cdot n_{i}\geq n_{next}-\tilde{n}.

where xi∈{0,1}subscript𝑥𝑖01x_{i}\in\{0,1\}. This is a knapsack problem and it can be solved by dynamic programming.
